State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, China University of Petroleum (East China) Qingdao Shandong 266580 China The resource utilization of CO2 serves as a feasible method for emission reduction and the establishment of an artificial carbon cycle. This study primarily focuses on the direct synthesis of dimethyl ether (DME) from the hydrogenation of CO2. We have prepared bifunctional catalysts with metal oxides embedded in amorphous silicon-aluminum by an improved Stöber method. By precisely adjusting the Si/Al molar ratio and the CTAB/Si molar ratio in the synthesis precursor solution, structural characteristics and acid properties of the catalyst could be effectively regulated. The results indicated that compared to Cu/ZnO/Al2O3, the catalyst significantly enhanced the selectivity of DME and methanol (MeOH), reduced the selectivity of CO with a moderate conversion rate of CO2. The highest DME selectivity of 37.94 % was achieved at an Si/Al ratio of 8, with the total selectivity for methanol and DME reaching 52.96 %. The addition of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) increased the proportion of Brønsted acid sites and medium-strong acid sites, thereby enhancing methanol dehydration and suppressing the reverse water-gas shift reaction. The optimal selectivity for DME of 43 % was obtained over catalyst prepared with a CTAB/Si molar ratio of 0.1. This study provides a new strategy for the structural design of bifunctional catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation. Due to the high thermodynamic stability of CO2 molecules and their potential as weak oxidizing agent, hydrogenation transformation of CO2 into oxygen-containing compounds was an ideal method. Among the oxygenated compounds from CO2 hydrogenation, methanol and dimethyl ether (DME) attracted significant attention due to their higher selectivity [3–5]. Methanol and DME were the most important basic raw materials in the chemical industry and could be used to synthesize a variety of high value-added chemical products, occupying an important position in the development of chemicals and materials. DME could not only be used as a fuel additive but also serve as a raw material for producing light olefins. The DMTO (dimethyl ether to olefins) process could be combined or replace the MTO (methanol to olefins) [6], and MTP (methanol to propylene) [7] processes. The thermodynamic results also indicated that the reaction of CO2 to DME had lower enthalpy and Gibbs free energy than the reaction of CO2 to methanol [8,9]. Further conversion of methanol to DME could break the thermodynamic limitations of CO2 to methanol and suppress the side reaction reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS). By calculating the equilibrium yields of DME and methanol in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, it was found that under the equilibrium yield of DME in the CO2 hydrogenation process is much higher than that of methanol under identical reaction conditions [10]. A typical DME synthesis bifunctional catalyst usually includes methanol synthesis components like Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 (CZA) and methanol dehydration components like acidic solid [11]. The commonly used combination methods were physical mixing method [12,13], impregnation method [14], co-precipitation method [15], etc. These methods were all designed to make the methanol synthesis component and the methanol dehydration component more efficiently coupled and to enhance the synergy of the two components. Ateka et al. [16] compared different combination strategies for CuO-ZnO-MnO and SAPO-18. The study found that when the two catalysts were mixed at an optimal mass ratio of 2/1 (methanol synthesis component/methanol dehydration component), the CO2 conversion rate of the catalyst prepared by the chemical loading method was twice that of the dual-bed strategy, with a 10 % increase in DME selectivity. This chemical loading strategy enhanced the "synthesis-dehydration" synergistic effect of methanol intermediates by constructing nanoscale intimate contact between metal-acidic sites, thereby improving the efficiency of methanol synthesis and dehydration. Yao et al. [17] demonstrated that the proximity of the two functional active centers facilitated the transfer of methoxy intermediates from methanol synthesis sites to dehydration sites. They further investigated the impact of different composite configurations on reaction pathways and discovered that when the two active centers were sufficiently close without mutual coverage, DME could be generated through a shortcut methoxy-DME pathway without requiring methanol formation as an intermediate, thereby more effectively enhancing DME selectivity. Bonura et al. [18] further explored the influence of mixed catalyst types on catalytic performance. They observed that catalysts composed of mechanically mixed Cu-ZnO-ZrO2 and HZSM-5 zeolite (mass ratio 1:1) outperformed chemically loaded catalysts. This phenomenon was attributed to the potential blockage of the zeolite's pores by metal particles during the metal loading process, which compromised catalytic performance. As a typical tandem reaction, CO2 was converted to methanol, and then methanol was dehydrated to DME. From the perspective of the reaction pathway, the core-shell structure and its similar structure are undoubtedly the most suitable catalyst configuration for complex reaction systems. The core-shell structure of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst made the intermediate methanol formed on the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 core more evenly mixed with the dehydration active site, which makes the reaction closer to the optimal transmission path [19–21]. This structure optimized the transport path of reactants compared to physically mixed or non-core-shell composite catalysts. Sanchez Contador et al. [22,23] prepared a CuO-ZnO-ZrO2@SAPO-11 core-shell catalyst using a physical bonding method with a SiO2 solution as the binder. In this configuration, methanol synthesis occurred in the CuO-ZnO-ZrO2 core, followed by diffusion and subsequent dehydration in the surrounding SAPO-11 acidic shell. For the hydrogenation of a CO2+CO mixture, this core-shell catalyst achieved a DME yield of 8.7 % and 81 % DME selectivity. The core-shell catalyst exhibited distinct advantages over mixed catalysts. The core-shell structure also effectively minimized adverse effects caused by interactions between different phases. Nie et al. [24] specifically emphasized the importance of confining Cu species within the core, which effectively prevented their migration to acidic functional regions, thereby maintaining the catalyst’s efficiency and stability. Although the physical bonding method was simple to implement, it often resulted in weak adhesion, and the presence of a SiO2 layer between the methanol synthesis and dehydration components covered some acidic sites, reducing DME selectivity. In addition to the physical bonding method, the core-shell structure could also be achieved by growing solid acids on the surface of metal oxides. However, there are various difficulties when growing zeolites on the surface of metal complexes in order to form a core-shell configuration. On the one hand, it was difficult to prepare defect-free H-type zeolite shells on the surface of metal oxides without precursors such as NaOH, KOH, Cl-, Br- in the synthesis solution [25]. If sodium hydroxide was added to prepare the zeolite shell, ion exchange was required, which could rapidly deactivate the metal compound core. On the other hand, metal oxide catalysts were prone to dissolution and dispersion during the hydrothermal synthesis process of the zeolite film. Zeolite, particularly ZSM-5, was the most commonly used methanol dehydration catalyst, but the strong acidic sites also encouraged the formation of by-products and the deposition of coke, resulting in catalyst deactivation. Numerous studies had proposed strategies to address the above issues. Yang et al. [26] successfully synthesized an HZSM-5 zeolite shell directly using an aluminum-free, near-neutral S-1 zeolite synthesis solution, where aluminum migrated from the CZA core catalyst to serve as the sole aluminum source for constructing the zeolite framework. During the synthesis, the aluminum-containing core catalyst acted both as a substrate for zeolite membrane growth and as the exclusive aluminum source, enabling defect-free and tightly wrapped coverage of the zeolite shell on its surface. Compared to traditional HZSM-5 zeolite membrane synthesis methods, this approach effectively minimized damage to the substrate caused by hydrothermal precursor solutions. Under reaction conditions of 523 K and 5.0 MPa, the catalyst prepared via the traditional HZSM-5 zeolite membrane method exhibited a CO2 conversion rate of 5.59 %, whereas the Silicalite-1 synthesis method increased CO2 conversion to 30.40 % with 78.57 % DME selectivity. Tsubaki et al. [25] first synthesized a neutral Silicalite-1 zeolite shell layer on a bimetallic Cr/ZnO core catalyst as an intermediate layer for the subsequent direct synthesis of an HZSM-5 zeolite shell. This dual-layer approach facilitated the formation of HZSM-5 membranes on millimeter-scale bimetallic substrates. The resulting zeolite capsule catalyst enabled precise control over DME synthesis, achieving 50.84 % DME selectivity under conditions of 623 K and 5.0 MPa. Embedding Cu-based catalysts into the bulk phase of solid acid catalysts to form embedded core-shell-like bifunctional catalysts also demonstrated excellent catalytic performance [27,28]. Sun et al. [28] prepared a bifunctional catalyst with Cu-ZnO particles fully embedded in mesoporous alumina by introducing pre-synthesized copper-zinc oxalate into an aluminum isopropoxide-containing precursor via an evaporation-induced assembly method. This embedded structure exhibited spatial confinement effects, which not only enhanced methanol dehydration rates but also suppressed Cu sintering during the reaction. According to our earlier research, amorphous silica-alumina species (SA) could also provide sufficient acid strength for dehydration. It was more moderate than ZSM-5 strong acid, which prevented the creation of coke and other byproducts [29]. The relatively mild synthesis conditions reduced the damage to metal oxides. However, the acid strength of amorphous silicon aluminum was too weak, which will led to the decrease of methanol dehydration. As a result, controlling the acidity of amorphous silicon aluminum remained challenging. Here, we described a simple procedure for embedding methanol synthesis component CZA into the methanol dehydration component SA using a modified Stöber method followed by dry-gel crystallization, which produced SA with good aluminum dispersion and improved acidity without significant destruction of CZA. The effects of initial Si/Al and CTAB/Si on the structure and acidity of the catalyst were systematically studied. XRD, XPS, TEM, BET and NMR characterization techniques were used to find the effect of this on the morphology, structural characteristics, coordination environment and acidic properties of SA after synthesis. The embedded structure catalyst was used for the direct synthesis of dimethyl ether from CO2. The effects of preparation conditions and reaction temperature on the catalytic performance were studied and discussed in detail. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation CuO-ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst (CZA) for methanol synthesis was synthesized using conventional co precipitation method [29], where the atomic ratio of Cu: Zn: Al was 6:3:1. Under stirring, A calculated amount of 0.1 mol/L Na2CO3 solution was added dropwise to a 0.1 mol/L mixed solution of Cu, Zn, and Al nitrate while stirring at the same drop rate, and the precipitation environment was kept at 65 °C and pH 6.5–7.5. Aging in a water bath under stirring conditions was lasted for another 1 hour after precipitation. The obtained precipitate is filtered, washed, dried, and then placed in a muffle furnace for 4 hours at 350 °C to obtain the methanol synthesis catalyst CZA. A embedded bifunctional catalyst, denoted as CZA@xSA-J-y, was prepared using the modified Stöber method [30] (x: the molar ratio of Si to Al in the initial raw materials, y: the molar ratio of CTAB to Si in the initial raw materials). The schematic diagram of catalyst synthesis is shown in Fig. 1(a). Typically, isopropyl alcohol aluminum (amount was calculated according to Si to Al molar ratios of 4.0, 8.0, and 12.0 in the initial raw materials) and a certain amount of CTAB (with CTAB to Si molar ratios of 0.4, 0.2, 0.1, 0.05, and 0) were added to 400 mL of anhydrous ethanol. After complete dissolution, 1 g of CZA was added to above prepared solution. Subsequently, 2.04 g of TEOS was dripped into the mixed solution. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for another 3 hours to allow complete hydrolysis of TEOS. Then, 40 mL of deionized water and 10 mL of ammonia water were added to the aforementioned suspension, which was further stirred at room temperature for an additional 4 hours. The suspension was filtered and washed with 2000 mL of pure water for several times. Next, a certain amount of CZA@xSA-y was placed into a polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) vial, which was positioned on top of a lining, with deionized water added below the lining (1 g of solid: 3 mL of water). The reaction vessel was then placed in a drying oven and treated at 150 °C for 48 hours. After the hydrothermal treatment, the samples were filtered, washed to neutral, and dried overnight in a 100 °C drying oven. The dried samples were calcined in a muffle furnace at a certain temperature for 6 hours to remove the organic compounds, resulting in the final catalyst, CZA@xSA-J-y. 2.2 Catalyst Characterization The catalyst was analyzed by X-ray diffraction using the X′ Pert Pro MPD polycrystalline powder X-ray diffractometer at 40 kV and 40 mA produced by Panaco in the Netherlands. The CO2 conversion rate and product selectivity were calculated using the carbon atom conservation method, and the calculation formula is as follows: (2-1) X CO 2 = ∑ i = 1 n n i f i A i / ( ∑ i = 1 n n i f i A i + f CO 2 A CO 2 ) × 100 % (2-2) S i = n i f i A i / ∑ i = 1 n n i f i A i × 100 % (2-3) Y i = X CO 2 × S i × 100 % Among them, X CO2, i, S i, n i, f i, A i and Y i represent CO2 conversion rate, different product components, selectivity of product i, number of carbon atoms in product i, correction factor of product i, peak area of product i, and yield of product i, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Firstly, we investigated the influence of different silicon-to-aluminum ratios on the structure and acidic characteristics of catalysts. Traditional Stöber method was firstly employed to prepare CZA@SiO2 without aluminum addition. The TEM image of the as-prepared CZA@SiO2 in Fig. 1(b) demonstrated that the average particle size of CZA metal oxide nanoparticles coated with pure SiO2 was 100 nm, which exhibited as spherical morphology. After adding an aluminum source, pure phase SiO2 spheres of the shell were transformed into flower-like silicoaluminate(SA)species, and the average particle size of metal oxide nanoparticles also decreased relatively. The surface of the CZA@4SA-J-0.2 (Fig. 1(e)) tended to flatten as the Si/Al ratio decreased to 4, and the coating effect deteriorated. Simultaneously, the particle size of CZA nanoparticles further decreased, and miscible phases containing Cu, Zn, Al, and Si gradually formed, with some CZA nanoparticles even being exposed on the shell surface. The element distribution of CZA@8SA-J-0.2 was shown by EDS (Fig. 1(g), Fig. S1), which also showed the uniform distribution of Si and Al throughout SA and the distribution of Cu in metal oxide particles. At the same time, it was observed that the metal oxide was relatively completely embedded into SA. Fig. S2 illustrated the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the embedded bifunctional catalyst CZA@8SA-J-0.2 and parent CZA. The XRD patterns of the catalysts revealed characteristic peaks corresponding to CuO (JCPDS NO. 41–0254) and ZnO (JCPDS NO. 36–1451). The dispersion peak at position 20°-30° indicated that the SA overlaying the CZA surface was amorphous. The N2 adsorption desorption results of catalysts with different Si/Al ratios were shown in Fig. 2(a)(b) and Table S1. The N2 adsorption-desorption curves were IV-type isotherms with H3-type hysteresis loops, indicating the catalyst's mesoporous structure. CZA@8SA-J-0.2 displayed high adsorption at relative pressures of 0.6–1.0, suggesting its pores were mainly slit-shaped, formed by the stacking of plate-like particles. The results of physical adsorption-desorption indicated that CZA@8SA-J-0.2 exhibited the largest specific surface area (208 m2/g) with the largest average pore diameter (6.73 nm), attributed to the existence of abundant flaky silicon aluminum species. In contrast, CZA@12SA-J-0.2 showed the highest micropore specific surface area, likely resulting from an excess silica source that promoted the formation of isolated SiO2 spheres. The XRF data (Table S2) demonstrated that the surface silicon-to-aluminum ratio of SA matched the feed silicon-to-aluminum ratio trend but with much lower values, which indicated that less silicon was crystallized on the surface during the dry-gel crystallization. Ammonia Temperature Programmed Desorption (NH3-TPD) analysis was conducted to investigate the surface acidity of the catalyst, and presented in Fig. 2(c) and Table S2. The TPD curves exhibited three distinct desorption peaks, which can be assigned to weak (W), medium (M), and strong (S) acid sites with desorption temperatures ranged at 120 °C, 280 °C, and 350 °C, respectively [31]. The weak acid sites were attributed to weakly adsorbed NH3 molecules on surface Si-OH or Al-OH groups [32]. The medium and strong acid sites were attributed to strongly adsorbed NH3 molecules on Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, respectively. As presented in Fig. 2(c) the CZA@12SA-J-0.2 catalyst had a significantly higher number of weak acid sites compared to CZA@8SA-J-0.2 and CZA@4SA-J-0.2, which was due to the excessive addition of silicon, leading to a remarkable increase in the number of surface Si-OH groups. Moreover, with a decrease in Si/Al, the total acidity tended to increase at first and subsequently decease. When the feeding Si/Al reached at ratio of 8, the proportion of strong and medium acids was the highest, which corresponds to its higher DME selectivity. However, aluminum species had a tendency to condense into neutral compounds like Al(OH)3 at low Si/Al ratios, which impaired dehydration efficiency. To further understand the mechanism of CTAB in the acid site formation of catalysts, a series of catalysts CZA@8SA-J-y (y = 0, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, and 0.4) were prepared by altering the amount of CTAB addition. As evidenced by TEM pictures (Fig. 1(c)(d)(f))), the catalyst without CTAB addition no longer had a flake-like morphology, and the surface of the SA tended to flatten. The results of N2 physical adsorption and desorption (Fig. 2(d)(e), Table 1) demonstrated that the specific surface area of the bifunctional catalyst was not significantly affected by the addition of CTAB. However, this resulted in a shift of the pore size distribution toward larger pore sizes. The average pore size of the catalyst increased with the increase of CTAB. The results of XRF (Table S3) showed that the silicon-to-aluminum ratio of the SA remained essentially consistent across varying CTAB addition levels. And XRF results showed that the catalyst contained only Cu, Zn, Si, Al, O elements, no Br and other impurity elements. This indicated that Br in CTAB was not retained in the catalyst, thereby ruling out the influence of Br on the catalyst. CTAB, as a cationic surfactant, likely adsorbed onto the negatively charged CZA particle surfaces via its positively charged head groups, while Br– counterions remained in the solution or were released into the synthesis medium during the adsorption process. However, NH3-TPD results (Table S3, Fig. 2(f)) indicated that the acidity of the SA were different. The proportion of medium and strong acids increased with higher CTAB content. However, the total acid content showed a downward trend, of which the maximum acid level of 2.452 mmol/g was obtained in CZA@8SA-J-0 (Table S3). The action mechanism of CTAB was further studied via vacuum transmission infrared spectroscopy ( Fig. 3). The catalysts exhibited a sharp IR peak near 3740 cm−1, which was primarily attributed to the stretching vibrations of isolated silanol (Si-OH) and aluminol (Al-OH) groups on the catalyst surface [33–35]. As the CTAB addition increased, the peak intensity at 3740 cm−1 gradually decreased, indicating that the isolated Si-OH and Al-OH groups underwent bonding interactions within the silicoaluminate matrix. Two primary bonding mechanisms were included. Firstly, upon calcination, CTAB decomposed, triggering the migration of metal ions (Cu and Zn) to the silicoaluminate surface. These ions reacted with surface hydroxyl groups (Si-OH and Al-OH), forming Cu(Zn)-O-Si and Cu(Zn)-O-Al bonds [36]. Simultaneously, Si-OH and Al-OH groups bonded to generate silicoaluminate bridging hydroxyl groups (Si-OH-Al) [33], which functioned as Brønsted acid sites critical for catalytic activity. The asymmetric stretching vibration peak of Si–O–Si bonds typically appeared near 1100 cm−1. However, due to the structural disorder inherent in amorphous materials compared to crystalline counterparts, this peak broadened or shifted in position. For amorphous silicoaluminate materials, the asymmetric stretching vibration of Si-O-Si bonds was observed across a range of 1050–1200 cm−1, while the vibrations of Si-O-M bonds (M: Al, Cu, Zn) occurred at 950–1050 cm−1 [37]. The formation of such Cu (Zn)-O-Si and Cu (Zn)-O-Al bonds can be further confirmed by XPS. The electronic states of Cu and Zn were determined by XPS at different levels of CTAB addition, as shown in Fig. 4. The binding energy (BE) of the Cu 2p peak of pure CZA catalyst located at 934.02 eV belongs to the Cu2+ oxidation state. The spectrum of Cu 2p in the CZA@8SA-J-y catalyst showed two peaks at around 933 eV and 935 eV, respectively, corresponding to two oxidation states of Cu+ and Cu2+. As the amount of CTAB added increased, the binding energy of Cu 2p3/2 orbitals increased. The reason for this phenomenon was that the bifunctional catalyst prepared with this method could facilitate the formation of Cu-O-Si and Cu-O-Al interfaces, which enhanced the metal-support interaction and promote an increase in the binding energy of Cu species [38]. Similarly, the binding energy of Zn 2p3/2 orbitals also increased with the increase of CTAB addition. H2-TPR results (Fig. S3(b)) showed that with the increase of CTAB content, the reduction temperature of the catalyst increased, which further proved that the binding energy of Cu species increased, and the catalyst was more difficult to be reduced. The concentration and strength of basic sites were evaluated through CO2-TPD experiments, with the results shown in Fig. S3(a) and Table S3. The desorption curve peaks could be divided into 200 °C, 400 °C, and 500 °C, which were attributed to weak, moderate, and strong basic sites on the catalyst surface, respectively. The weak basic sites resulted from CO2 binding to surface OH- groups, while the moderate basic sites were due to CO2 binding to metal-oxygen pairs (Cu-O and Zn-O). The strong basic sites arose from CO2 adsorption on surface O2- anions. It was noted that the amount of desorbed CO2 molecules increased with higher CTAB content (Table S3), along with an increased proportion of desorption from strong basic sites. This indicated that the addition of more CTAB could promote the number of CO2 adsorption active centers. This might be attributed to the fact that higher CTAB content facilitated the disintegration of the Cu-ZnO structure and the dispersion of CuO, exposing more oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface. This also explained the increased CO2 conversion rate of CZA@8SA-J-0.4. To further elucidate the impact of CTAB addition on aluminum coordination and the formation mechanism of Brønsted acid sites (e.g., Si-OH-Al bridging hydroxyl groups), one-dimensional 1D nuclear magnetic resonance aluminum spectra spectroscopy was employed. The results of 1D 27Al MAS NMR ( Fig. 5, Table 2) showed that the amount of Al VI decreased with the addition of CTAB, while the amount of Al IV and Al V increased. As is well known, Al IV and Al VI were the main Al coordination sites on amorphous SA. When strongly distorted or metastable aluminum atoms (Al IV and Al V) were incorporated into the vicinity of silanol groups, the local structure of silanol groups near aluminum exhibited a "pseudo bridged silanol" model(as shown in Scheme 1) [37,39]. These metastable aluminums could undergo electron transfer to adjacent Si-OH groups, thereby enhancing the acidity of adjacent silanol groups and forming Brønsted acid sites [40]. 3.2 Catalytic performance for CO 2 hydrogenation Catalytic performances of CO2 hydrogenation to DME were conducted as a result of CO2 conversion and product selectivity, as shown in Fig. 6 and Tables S5-S7. The main by-product of the reaction was CO, with a small amount of CH4, but no C2+ hydrocarbons were detected. Compared with the CZA catalyst, the bifunctional catalyst significantly reduced the selectivity of CO after the introduction of acidic components. Taking CZA@8SA-J-0.1 as an example, the CO selectivity of the CZA catalyst was 70.45 % (Table S4), while the CO selectivity of CZA@8SA-J-0.1 was reduced to 43.46 %. To investigate the effect of the Si/Al ratio on the performance of the bifunctional catalyst, a series of catalysts with varying Si/Al ratios (denoted as CZA@xSA-J-0.2, x = 4, 8, 12) were tested (Fig. 6(a), Table S5). The catalyst with Si/Al ratio of 8 exhibited the highest selectivity for DME at 37.94 %, with a combined selectivity for methanol and DME of 52.96 %. This superior performance was attributed to the optimal Si/Al ratio, which endowed CZA@8SA-J-0.2 with the highest total acidity and the highest proportion of medium-strong acid sites. The catalyst CZA@12SA-J-0.2 showed a DME selectivity of 36.39 % and a combined selectivity for methanol and DME of 50 %, which was close to the performance of CZA@8SA-J-0.2. However, the acid amount of CZA@12SA-J-0.2 (1.381 mmol/g) was significantly lower than that of CZA@8SA-J-0.2 (1.877 mmol/g). This indicated that increasing the amount of aluminum source does not significantly enhance the dehydration of methanol. Excessive aluminum addition did not promote better combination between silicon and aluminum, and the independently nucleated aluminum species increased the number of weak acid sites on the catalyst. The increase in acid amount was primarily due to the adsorption of NH3 on the surface-rich Al-OH groups. Further reducing the Si/Al ratio, the catalyst CZA@4SA-J-0.2 had an increased proportion of weak acid sites, but the DME selectivity decreased to 29.20 %. Catalysts CZA@8SA-J-y with varying CTAB/Si ratios from 0 to 0.4 were further evaluated, and the results are summarized in Fig. 6(b) and Table S6. As the CTAB/Si ratio increased from 0 to 0.1, the selectivity for DME increased from 26.10 % to 43.00 %, and the selectivity for CO decreased from 61.29 % to 43.46 %. However, according to the NH3-TPD results (Table S3), CZA@8SA-J-0 and CZA@8SA-J-0.1 catalysts exhibit comparable acid amounts but different methanol dehydration performances. According to the 1D 27Al MAS NMR results (Fig. 5), the addition of CTAB changed the aluminum coordination, increasing the amount of Brønsted acid sites by raising the levels of Al IV and Al V. The increased Brønsted acid sites enhance the dehydration performance, which also explains why the CZA@8SA-J-0.1 catalyst exhibits better methanol dehydration properties, despite having a similar acid amount to the CZA@8SA-J-0 catalyst. Additionally, Al V species have been identified as defects in Al VI species with oxygen vacancies and can also act as Lewis acid sites, which can catalyze a variety of reactions, such as alcohol dehydration [41–43]. The synergy between acid sites can significantly improve the performance in acid-catalyzed reactions. The CO2 conversion decreased from 11.47 % to 9.44 %, which may be due to the suppressed RWGS reaction. However, as further increasing the amount of CTAB from 0.1 to 0.4, the selectivity of DME for the CZA@8SA-J-y catalyst decreased from 43.00 % to 27.80 %, and CO selectivity increased from 43.46 % to 60.53 %. According to literature [44,45], both the structural characteristics and surface acidity of catalyst could significantly affect the performance of methanol dehydration. The restrictive effect of the pore structure could also affect the accessible acid amount during the actual reaction process. According to the results of N2 adsorption and desorption (Table 1), it was found that the increase in CTAB addition caused the pore size distribution to shift towards larger pores. Wang Yan et al. found that there is no linear relationship between the specific surface area and the CO2 to DME reaction activity of the bifunctional catalyst [21], but there were differences in the synthesis of DME from methanol over dehydration active site with different pore sizes. This was also consistent with the experimental results of adding CTAB at a dosage of 0.1–0.4. Jones et al. provided an explanation for this phenomenon. They [46] found that as the pore size decreased, the local electric field's van der Waals interaction force with the transition state of the reactants increased, and reducing the reaction energy barrier and thus increasing the reaction activity. The limitation of pore structure could also affect the amount of acid that could be reached during the actual reaction process. We correlated the total acid amount, average pore size, and DME yield and found that within the range of CTAB/Si values from 0.1 to 0.4, there was no clear correlation between the total acid amount and DME yield, but there was a strong negative correlation between the average pore size and DME yield (Fig. 6(c)). The effect of catalysts at different reaction temperatures on CO2 conversion was also conducted and the results could be seen from Fig. 6(d) and Table S7. As the reaction temperature increased from 200 °C to 290 °C, the conversion of CO2 also increased. The highest conversion rate of CO2 of 12.56 % was obtained when the reaction was operated at 290 °C. As the reaction temperature continued to rise, the CO2 conversion began to decline, indicating that the reaction kinetics were the primary limiting factor for the conversion of carbon dioxide to methanol at low temperatures. As the reaction temperature continued to increase, the reaction had a tendency to shift towards the positive direction at high temperatures while the thermodynamics of the reaction became dominated, and RWGS reaction was enhanced, which leading to a gradually decrease on DME selectivity. A 48-hour reaction stability test was conducted on the CZA@8SA-J-0.1 catalyst at 260 °C and 3 MPa. Reaction performance was recorded every 2 hours during the test. The result was shown in Fig. S4. After 20 of reaction, the CO2 conversion rate exhibited a declining trend, while the selectivity toward methanol and DME generally continued to rise. After 40 hours of reaction, the selectivity of the target products began to show a moderate decline. Throughout the entire process, minor fluctuations in methanol and DME selectivity were observed, but the overall performance remained stable. The CZA@xSA-J-y catalyst prepared in this study exhibited excellent catalytic performance in the direct CO2 hydrogenation to dimethyl ether (DME). Compared with previously reported catalysts (Table S8), the present catalyst achieved moderate-to-high DME selectivity under comparable reaction conditions. Specifically, comprehensive characterization analyses revealed that its unique surface acidity and structural features facilitated methanol dehydration. The core-shell-like structure of CZA@xSA-J-y enhanced DME selectivity compared to the conventional CZA/SA catalyst [29]. Furthermore, relative to the hydrothermally synthesized CZAS@SA catalyst, the preparation method in this study not only retained the effective confinement effect of the shell layer on the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 core catalyst [47] but also avoided structural damage to the core caused by harsh hydrothermal synthesis environments, thereby achieving higher CO2 conversion rates. In situ DRIFTS analysis was further conducted on the CO2 hydrogenation reaction over the CZA@8SA-J-0.1 catalyst to verify surface intermediates. The results were shown in Fig. 7. The bands near 2340 cm−1 and 2332 cm−1 were attributed to CO2 adsorbed on the catalyst surface. CO2 exhibited two distinct adsorption states on the catalyst surface: monodentate carbonate (1450 cm−1) and bidentate carbonate (1530 cm−1). As reported by G. Bonura et al., CO2 was converted into carbonates on copper active sites, followed by a stepwise hydrogenation pathway via formate species ("O-C-O→(HO-COO-)→HCOO-→HOCHO-→HOCH2O-→CH2O(+HO-)→CH3O-") to ultimately form methoxy species [47]. Through DRIFTS measurements at multiple temperatures, the characteristic peaks detected at 1338 cm−1 and 1594 cm−1 were assigned to adsorbed formate (*HCOO), while the peak at 1690 cm−1 corresponded to formic acid (*HCOOH) [48]. Their intensities were relatively low at lower temperatures. Concurrently, methoxy species (CH3O*) were identified on the catalyst surface (1079 cm−1), along with gaseous DME (937 cm−1, 1201 cm−1). The formation of surface formate and methoxy intermediates confirmed methanol production via the formate pathway. Subsequently, two co-adsorbed methanol molecules underwent coupling on Brønsted acid sites of the dehydration component to form DME (associative mechanism), or one adsorbed methanol molecule first dissociated into surface methoxy species, which then reacted with another methanol molecule to produce DME (dissociative mechanism) [49,50]. However, for both cases the methanol condensation is consistent with the cooperation of Brønsted acidic sites located on the dehydration component [51,52]. Two types of surface-adsorbed CO were observed at 1940 cm−1 (bridged CO) and 2159 cm−1 (linear CO). Increasing the reaction temperature promoted the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction, leading to an enhanced amount of adsorbed CO on the catalyst surface. 4 Conclusion In summary, CuO-ZnO-Al2O3 embedded amorphous silicoaluminate was prepared by combination of co-precipitation method and improved Stöber method. By simply adjusting the Si/Al and CTAB/Si molar ratio of the precursors, the structural and acid properties of the catalyst could be accurately controlled. The total acid content of preparing catalyst firstly increased first and then decreased as Si/Al decrease. The maximum percentage of medium-strong acid and strong acid was obtained when Si/Al was 8, which corresponds to the higher DME selectivity of 37.94 %. The coordination type of Al could be altered by the addition of CTAB, resulting in the increase the proportion of metastable aluminum (Al IV and Al V) responsible for Brønsted acid generation. Moreover, the increase of CTAB could also enhance the interaction between silicon and aluminum and reduce the independent nucleation of neutral Al(OH)3 species. However, the addition of excessive CTAB would increase the average pore size of the catalyst and reduce the amount of accessible acid sites, resulting in a decrease of dehydration performance. The highest selectivity of DME is 43 % was obtained on the catalyst prepared with the CTAB/Si molar ratio of 0.1. In conclusion, the reported method provides an effective strategy for the preparation of bifunctional core-shell-like structure catalysts with high activity and selectivity of CO2 hydrogenation to DME. coredata.dc:description: The resource utilization of CO2 serves as a feasible method for emission reduction and the establishment of an artificial carbon cycle. This study primarily focuses on the direct synthesis of dimethyl ether (DME) from the hydrogenation of CO2. We have prepared bifunctional catalysts with metal oxides embedded in amorphous silicon-aluminum by an improved Stöber method. By precisely adjusting the Si/Al molar ratio and the CTAB/Si molar ratio in the synthesis precursor solution, structural characteristics and acid properties of the catalyst could be effectively regulated. The results indicated that compared to Cu/ZnO/Al2O3, the catalyst significantly enhanced the selectivity of DME and methanol (MeOH), reduced the selectivity of CO with a moderate conversion rate of CO2. The highest DME selectivity of 37.94 % was achieved at an Si/Al ratio of 8, with the total selectivity for methanol and DME reaching 52.96 %. The addition of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) increased the proportion of Brønsted acid sites and medium-strong acid sites, thereby enhancing methanol dehydration and suppressing the reverse water-gas shift reaction. The optimal selectivity for DME of 43 % was obtained over catalyst prepared with a CTAB/Si molar ratio of 0.1. This study provides a new strategy for the structural design of bifunctional catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation.
